inputSetence1:
Fade in on a jury box. Twelve men are seated in it, listening intently to the voice of the judge as he charges
them. We do not see the judge. He speaks in slow, measured tones, and his voice is grave. The camera drifts
over the faces of the jurymen as the judge speaks, and we see that most of their heads are turned to camera's
left. NO. 7 looks down at his hands. NO. 3 looks off in another direction, the direction in which the defendant
would be sitting. NO. 10 keeps moving his head back and forth nervously. The judge drones on.
inputSetence2:
JUDGE: Murder in the first degree—premeditated homicide—is the most serious charge tried in our criminal
courts. You've heard a long and complex case, gentlemen, and it is now your duty to sit down to try and
separate the facts from the fancy. One man is dead. The life of another is at stake. If there is a reasonable doubt
in your minds as to the guilt of the accused . . . then you must declare him not guilty. If, however, there is no
reasonable doubt, then he must be found guilty. Whichever way you decide, the verdict must be unanimous. I
urge you to deliberate honestly and thoughtfully. You are faced with a grave responsibility. Thank you,
gentlemen.
inputSetence3: [There is a long pause.]
inputSetence4: CLERK: (droning). The jury will retire.

box and off camera to the left. Camera holds on jury box, and then fades out].

inputSetence1:
[Fade in on a large bare, unpleasant-looking room. This is the jury room in the county criminal court of a large
Eastern city. It is about 4:00 P.M. The room is furnished with a long conference table and a dozen chairs. The
walls are bare, drab and badly in need of a fresh coat of paint. Along one wall is a row of windows, which look
out on the skyline of the city's financial district. High on another wall is an electric clock. A washroom opens off
the jury room. In one corner of the room is a water fountain. On the table are pads, pencils, and ashtrays. One
of the windows is open. Papers blow across the table and onto the floor as the door opens. Lettered on the
outside of the door are the words "Jury Room". A uniformed guard holds the door open. Slowly, almost self-
consciously, the twelve jurors file in. The guard counts them as they enter the door, his lips moving, but no
sound coming forth. Four or five of the jurors light cigarettes as they enter the room. Juror NO. 5 lights his
pipe, which he smokes constantly throughout the play. Jurors NO. 2 and 12 go to the water fountain. NO. 9
goes into the washroom, the door of which is lettered "Men." Several of the jurors take seats at the table. Others
stand awkwardly around the room. Several look out the windows. These are men who are ill at ease, who do not
really know each other to talk to and who wish they were anywhere but here. NO. 7, standing at window, takes
out a pack of gum, takes a piece, and offers it around. There are no takers. He mops his brow.]

inputSetence4: MARY: Elizabeth and Donald are now too happy to be able to hear me. I can therefore let you in on a secret. Elizabethis not Elizabeth, Donald is not Donald. And here is the proof: the child that Donald spoke of is not Elizabeth'sdaughter, they are not the same person. Donald's daughter has one white eye and one red eye like Elizabeth's daughter.Whereas Donald's child has a white right eye and a red left eye, Elizabeth's child has a red right eye and a white lefteye! Thus all of Donald's system of deduction collapses when it comes up against this last obstacle which destroys hiswhole theory. In spite of the extraordinary coincidences which seem to be definitive proofs, Donald and Elizabeth, notbeing the parents of the same child, are not Donald and Elizabeth. It is in vain that he thinks he is Donald, it is in vainthat she thinks she is Elizabeth. He believes in vain that she is Elizabeth. She believes in vain that he is Donald -theyare sadly deceived. But who is the true Donald? Who is the true Elizabeth? Who has any interest in prolonging thisconfusion? I don't know. Let's not try to know. Let's leave things as they are. [She takes several steps toward the door,then returns and says to the audience:] My real name is Sherlock Holmes. [She exits.][The clock strikes as much as it likes. randomFifthSentence2: POZZO:In reality he carries like a pig. It's not his job.

inputSetence1: POZZO:He imagines that when I see him indefatigable I'll regret my decision. Such is hismiserable scheme. As though I were short of slaves! (All three look at Lucky.)Atlas, son of Jupiter! (Silence.) Well, that's that, I think. Anything else?Vaporizer.
inputSetence2: VLADIMIR:You want to get rid of him?
inputSetence3: POZZO:Remark that I might just as well have been in his shoes and he in mine. If chancehad not willed otherwise. To each one his due.
inputSetence4: VLADIMIR:You waagerrim?
randomFifthSentence1: POZZO:I beg your pardon?
randomFifthSentence2: VLADIMIR:I think so too.Silence.

inputSetence1: POZZO:I do. But instead of driving him away as I might have done, I mean instead ofsimply kicking him out on his arse, in the goodness of my heart I am bringing himto the fair, where I hope to get a good price for him. The truth is you can't drivesuch creatures away. The best thing would be to kill them.Lucky weeps.
inputSetence2: ESTRAGON:He's crying!
inputSetence3: POZZO:Old dogs have more dignity. (He proffers his handkerchief to Estragon.) Comforthim, since you pity him. (Estragon hesitates.) Come on. (Estragon takes thehandkerchief.) Wipe away his tears, he'll feel less forsaken.Estragon hesitates.
inputSetence4: VLADIMIR:Here, give it to me, I'll do it.Estragon refuses to give the handkerchief.Childish gestures.
randomFifthSentence1: ESTRAGON:I wonder.
randomFifthSentence2: POZZO:Make haste, before he stops. (Estragon approaches Lucky and makes to wipe hiseyes. Lucky kicks him violently in the shins. Estragon drops the handkerchief,recoils, staggers about the stage howling with pain.) Hanky!Lucky puts down bag and basket, picks up handkerchief and gives it to Pozzo,goes back to his place, picks up bag and basket.

inputSetence1: VLADIMIR:(to Estragon). Show me. (Estragon shows his leg. To Pozzo, angrily.) He'sbleeding!
inputSetence2: POZZO:It's a good sign.
inputSetence3: ESTRAGON:(on one leg). I'll never walk again!
inputSetence4: VLADIMIR:(tenderly). I'll carry you. (Pause.) If necessary.
randomFifthSentence1: ESTRAGON:His correspondents.VLADIMIR:His books.
randomFifthSentence2: POZZO:He's stopped crying. (To Estragon.) You have replaced him as it were. (Lyrically.)The tears of the world are a constant quantity. For each one who begins to weep,somewhere else another stops. The same is true of the laugh. (He laughs.) Let usnot then speak ill of our generation, it is not any unhappier than its predecessors.(Pause.) Let us not speak well of it either. (Pause.) Let us not speak of it at all.(Pause. Judiciously.) It is true the population has increased.

inputSetence1: POZZO:Guess who taught me all these beautiful things. (Pause. Pointing to Lucky.) MyLucky!
inputSetence2: VLADIMIR:(looking at the sky.) Will night never come?
inputSetence3: POZZO:But for him all my thoughts, all my feelings, would have been of common things.(Pause. With extraordinary vehemence.) Professional worries! (Calmer.) Beauty,grace, truth of the first water, I knew they were all beyond me. So I took a knook.
inputSetence4: VLADIMIR:(startled from his inspection of the sky). A knook?
randomFifthSentence1: ESTRAGON:Or Thursday?
randomFifthSentence2: POZZO:That was nearly sixty years ago . . . (he consults his watch) . . . yes, nearly sixty.(Drawing himself up proudly.) You wouldn't think it to look at me, would you?Compared to him I look like a young man, no? (Pause.) Hat! (Lucky puts downthe basket and takes off his hat. His long white hair falls about his face. He putshis hat under his arm and picks up the basket.) Now look. (Pozzo takes off hishat. [All four wear bowlers.] He is completely bald. He puts on his hat again.) Didyou see?

inputSetence1: ESTRAGON:Swine!Pozzo more and more agitated.VLADIMIR:After having sucked all the good out of him you chuck him away like a . . . like abanana skin. Really . . .
inputSetence2: POZZO:(groaning, clutching his head). I can't bear it . . . any longer . . . the way he goeson . . . you've no idea . . . it's terrible . . . he must go . . . (he waves his arms) . . .I'm going mad . . . (he collapses, his head in his hands) . . . I can't bear it . . . anylonger . . .Silence. All look at Pozzo.
inputSetence3: VLADIMIR:He can't bear it.
inputSetence4: ESTRAGON:Any longer.
randomFifthSentence1: VLADIMIR:He's going mad.
randomFifthSentence2: VLADIMIR:We'll come back tomorrow.

inputSetence1: VLADIMIR:(to Lucky). How dare you! It's abominable! Such a good master! Crucify him likethat! After so many years! Really!
inputSetence2: POZZO:(sobbing). He used to be so kind . . . so helpful . . . and entertaining . . . my goodangel . . . and now . . . he's killing me.
inputSetence3: ESTRAGON:( to Vladimir). Does he want to replace him?
inputSetence4: VLADIMIR:What?
randomFifthSentence1: VLADIMIR:You can ask him now. He's on the alert.
randomFifthSentence2: ESTRAGON:Does he want someone to take his place or not?

inputSetence1: ESTRAGON:What?
inputSetence2: VLADIMIR:I don't know.
inputSetence3: ESTRAGON:Ask him.
inputSetence4: POZZO:(calmer). Gentlemen, I don't know what came over me. Forgive me. Forget all Isaid. (More and more his old self.) I don't remember exactly what it was, but youmay be sure there wasn't a word of truth in it. (Drawing himself up, striking hischest.) Do I look like a man that can be made to suffer? Frankly? (He rummagesin his pockets.) What have I done with my pipe?
randomFifthSentence1: VLADIMIR:Charming evening we're having.
randomFifthSentence2: VLADIMIR:(vehemently). Let's go!

inputSetence1: VLADIMIR:And it's not over.
inputSetence2: ESTRAGON:Apparently not.
inputSetence3: VLADIMIR:It's only beginning.
inputSetence4: ESTRAGON:It's awful.
randomFifthSentence1: VLADIMIR:Let me go!ESTRAGON:Stay where you are!
randomFifthSentence2: VLADIMIR:Worse than the pantomime.

inputSetence1: VLADIMIR:The music-hall.
inputSetence2: ESTRAGON:The circus.
inputSetence3: POZZO:What can I have done with that briar?
inputSetence4: ESTRAGON:He's a scream. He's lost his dudeen.Laughs noisily.
randomFifthSentence1: VLADIMIR:Together again at last! We'll have to celebrate this. But how? (He reflects.) Get uptill I embrace you.
randomFifthSentence2: VLADIMIR:I'll be back.He hastens towards the wings.

inputSetence1: VLADIMIR:Keep my seat.Exit Vladimir.
inputSetence2: POZZO:(on the point of tears). I've lost my Kapp and Peterson!
inputSetence3: ESTRAGON:(convulsed with merriment). He'll be the death of me!
inputSetence4: POZZO:You didn't see by any chance– (He misses Vladimir.) Oh! He's gone! Withoutsaying goodbye! How could he! He might have waited!
randomFifthSentence1: ESTRAGON:He would have burst.
randomFifthSentence2: ESTRAGON:It's the normal thing.

inputSetence1: ESTRAGON:Come here.
inputSetence2: POZZO:What for?
inputSetence3: ESTRAGON:You'll see.
inputSetence4: POZZO:You want me to get up?
randomFifthSentence1: ESTRAGON:Quick! (Pozzo gets up and goes over beside Estragon. Estragon points off.) Look!
randomFifthSentence2: ESTRAGON:In a ditch.

inputSetence1: ESTRAGON:It's all over.Enter Vladimir, somber. He shoulders Lucky out of his way, kicks over the stool,comes and goes agitatedly.
inputSetence2: POZZO:He's not pleased.
inputSetence3: ESTRAGON:(to Vladimir). You missed a treat. Pity.Vladimir halts, straightens the stool, comes and goes, calmer.
inputSetence4: POZZO:He subsides. (Looking round.) Indeed all subsides. A great calm descends.(Raising his hand.) Listen! Pan sleeps.
randomFifthSentence1: VLADIMIR:Hmm. It'd give us an erection.
randomFifthSentence2: VLADIMIR:Will night never come?All three look at the sky.

inputSetence1: ESTRAGON:Well you see—
inputSetence2: POZZO:Why it's very natural, very natural. I myself in your situation, if I had anappointment with a Godin . . . Godet . . . Godot . . . anyhow, you see who I mean,I'd wait till it was black night before I gave up. (He looks at the stool.) I'd verymuch like to sit down, but I don't quite know how to go about it.
inputSetence3: ESTRAGON:Could I be of any help?
inputSetence4: POZZO:If you asked me perhaps.
randomFifthSentence1: ESTRAGON:Why doesn't he put down his bags?
randomFifthSentence2: ESTRAGON:What?

inputSetence1: ESTRAGON:Would that be a help?
inputSetence2: POZZO:I fancy so.
inputSetence3: ESTRAGON:Here we go. Be seated, Sir, I beg of you.
inputSetence4: POZZO:No no, I wouldn't think of it! (Pause. Aside.) Ask me again.
randomFifthSentence1: ESTRAGON:Come come, take a seat I beseech you, you'll get pneumonia.
randomFifthSentence2: ESTRAGON:He would have burst.

inputSetence1: ESTRAGON:Why it's absolutely certain.
inputSetence2: POZZO:No doubt you are right. (He sits down.) Done it again! (Pause.) Thank you, dearfellow. (He consults his watch.) But I must really be getting along, if I am toobserve my schedule.
inputSetence3: VLADIMIR:Time has stopped.
inputSetence4: POZZO:(cuddling his watch to his ear). Don't you believe it, Sir, don't you believe it. (Heputs his watch back in his pocket.) Whatever you like, but not that.
randomFifthSentence1: ESTRAGON:Oh tray bong, tray tray tray bong.
randomFifthSentence2: ESTRAGON:(to Pozzo). Everything seems black to him today.

inputSetence1: VLADIMIR:Let's go.
inputSetence2: ESTRAGON:But take the weight off your feet, I implore you, you'll catch your death.
inputSetence3: POZZO:True. (He sits down. To Estragon.) What is your name?
inputSetence4: ESTRAGON:Adam.

Look! (All look at the sky except Lucky who is dozing off again. Pozzo jerksthe rope.) Will you look at the sky, pig! (Lucky looks at the sky.) Good, that'senough. (They stop looking at the sky.) What is there so extraordinary about it?Qua sky. It is pale and luminous like any sky at this hour of the day. (Pause.) Inthese latitudes. (Pause.) When the weather is fine. (Lyrical.) An hour ago (helooks at his watch, prosaic) roughly (lyrical) after having poured forth even since(he hesitates, prosaic) say ten o'clock in the morning (lyrical) tirelessly torrents ofred and white light it begins to lose its effulgence, to grow pale (gesture of the twohands lapsing by stages) pale, ever a little paler, a little paler until (dramaticpause, ample gesture of the two hands flung wide apart) pppfff! finished! it comesto rest. But– (hand raised in admonition)– but behind this veil of gentleness andpeace, night is charging (vibrantly) and will burst upon us (snaps his fingers) pop!like that! (his inspiration leaves him) just when we least expect it. (Silence.Gloomily.) That's how it is on this bitch of an earth.Long silence.

inputSetence1: VLADIMIR:One can bide one's time.
inputSetence2: ESTRAGON:One knows what to expect.
inputSetence3: VLADIMIR:No further need to worry.
inputSetence4: ESTRAGON:Simply wait.
randomFifthSentence1: VLADIMIR:We're used to it.He picks up his hat, peers inside it, shakes it, puts it on.
randomFifthSentence2: ESTRAGON:(irritably). Not now, not now.

inputSetence1: VLADIMIR:(first to understand). Oh very good, very very good.
inputSetence2: POZZO:(to Estragon). And you, Sir?
inputSetence3: ESTRAGON:Oh tray bong, tray tray tray bong.
inputSetence4: POZZO:(fervently). Bless you, gentlemen, bless you! (Pause.) I have such need ofencouragement! (Pause.) I weakened a little towards the end, you didn't notice?

randomFifthSentence2: ESTRAGON:(to Vladimir). You missed a treat. Pity.Vladimir halts, straightens the stool, comes and goes, calmer.

inputSetence1: ESTRAGON:Not at all!
inputSetence2: VLADIMIR:What an idea!
inputSetence3: POZZO:Yes yes, you have been correct. So that I ask myself is there anything I can do inmy turn for these honest fellows who are having such a dull, dull time.
inputSetence4: ESTRAGON:Even ten francs would be a help.
randomFifthSentence1: VLADIMIR:We are not beggars!
randomFifthSentence2: POZZO:I present myself: Pozzo.

inputSetence1: ESTRAGON:Even five.
inputSetence2: VLADIMIR:(to Estragon, indignantly). That's enough!
inputSetence3: ESTRAGON:I couldn't accept less.

(He picks up the whip.) What do you prefer? Shall we have himdance, or sing, or recite, or think, or—
randomFifthSentence1: ESTRAGON:Who?
randomFifthSentence2: ESTRAGON:Come come, take a seat I beseech you, you'll get pneumonia.

inputSetence1: VLADIMIR:He thinks?

inputSetence3: ESTRAGON:I'd rather he dance, it'd be more fun.
inputSetence4: POZZO:Not necessarily.

inputSetence4: VLADIMIR:Then let him dance.Silence.

inputSetence2: ESTRAGON:Is that all?
inputSetence3: POZZO:Encore!Lucky executes the same movements, stops.
